When I get older an can't tour under my own power, I plan on getting and ebike. For now I'm quite happy with my touring and road bikes. And happy not to judge others.

data.text: Yes, we did a 3 day San Juan Islands covering 3 islands last year. I don't feel it makes any difference what bike I am riding as long as it is a bike.
data.author: Janice Eddington
Janice Eddington

data.text: that is a big assumption. I have pedals and use them, alot, I use my bike to excerise. Many days I don't turn it on, have you tried to pedal a 65lb bike. I will do that for 15 or 20 miles, then I turn on pedal assist one. My goal at that level is to turn the pedals faster and harder so the battery does not engage. But many times we want to go farther, 40, 50, OR 60 miles, or I get a crazy hair and we do 80 miles and with a Iittle assist I can do it. Most ebikes can go about 20 miles on the battery without pedaling. The ebike allows me go farther, explore more, and have a more active lifestyle. I have a bicyle, not a scooter.

data.text: Yes, but so far only in UK. later this year probably in France.
data.author: Tony Dobbs

data.text: Don't pay any attention to the "purist snobs" on this page. A lot of people tour on e-bikes and typically carry an extra battery. However, note that many e-bike tourists will stay in hotels/motels for charging purposes as opposed to camping or alternate between hotels/motels and camping. You do what works for you and leave the haters in the dust as you live your adventures. You certainly don't need their approval or their negativity.
data.author: Gabi Gee

data.text: Yep!

data.text: No, it's about how it is expressed and a lot of the ebike dislike comes from people who think it's cheating and get judgemental. If I ride an ebike in a race, yeah, that's cheating. If I ride an ebike while touring, that's my decision and has zero impact on the strangers riding around me. So maybe chill out and go ride whatever bike you prefer, electronic or not.

data.text: Yes I do .for many years I toured on a 1960 Carlton which I still have .but now at the age of 79 what have I got to prove.i don‚Äôt have it switched on all the time only on steeper hills .that way I get over 200 miles on one charge
data.author: Roy Pink

data.text: and THAT'S the key fact that a lot of people forget. Using the assist is an OPTION. Question: Is your e-bike, without gear, very heavy? I've done weekend tours on my steel touring bike but not on the e-bike yet, so I guess I'm curious about that.
data.author: Gabi Gee

data.text: yes it heavier.but to bbe honest I don‚Äôt notice the difference.I think if you were to put the Carlton and the giant ebike side by side on the same trip .yes there Would be a slight difference but as you only ride one at time it‚Äôs not noticeable .and you get the same exercise.on two trips one on the Carlton one on the giant .average heart rate Carlton 89 giant ebike 86 same trip .let‚Äôs face it the weight difference is only 10 pounds .and there‚Äôs a lot of riders out there 2 stone heavy than me and that differers is 28 pounds .just get on that ebike and enjoy it .in the future as batters get smaller and lighter all touring bikes will be electric.then you will have the choice to switch it on of not
data.author: Roy Pink

data.text: my eBike is heavy without gear, but not as heavy as touring loaded up without it. I just turn it on when needed. The issue is, and it‚Äôs a mental one, if you‚Äôve had the assist on and then turn it off, it does feel like you‚Äôre towing an open parachute for a bit until you get into a new rhythm.

data.text: yeah I find that . But I think that‚Äôs because you have turned it off to soon and it‚Äôs still climbing

data.text: I toured before bikes got motors, & used maps rather than cellphone apps.... I never had 'range anxiety' as a result. & now have a map collection with the route highlighted , & snapshots on film I had to get processed then prints on paper..
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: I'm planning on it. In fact idk if I'd have the guts for a long distance tour if my trike *wasn't* motorized.
data.author: Randall Stone

data.text: In 2019 I was touring North along the Belgium / Dutch coast with my 25kg+ bike and luggage, feeling a bit perturbed by the number of crinkly peeps with white hair leaving me behind. Especially uphill and into the wind. It turned out they were all on ebikes. In the end I just embraced them and tucked in, might as well get a tow! I have since taught people to ride ebikes. Every bike rider is better than a car driver! E is the revolution and one day I will join them!

data.text: I don't like e-bikes. Because I think bikes are good for fitness. What do you think?

data.text: if you ride a pedal assist ebike then you are getting exercise. You pedal‚Ä¶..assistance isn‚Äôt automatic, you have to turn it on and it only works if you pedal. Ebike shave allowed a lot of people the opportunity to exercise by riding a bike that wouldn‚Äôt be able without assistance. Throttle only ebike on the other hand is different.
data.author: Gaye Brewer

data.text: What I think is dependent on the operator. IF you are pushing then your pushing. If your lax, then your lax. Now for the rest: This is a most excellent post! I am curious about weight for those of you that have toured with an EB! My weight lmit on my EB is 300 lbs. IF/When I add a second battery that will push me over that limit, especially IF i load up with too much food. Has that not been a problem? Personally I'm fighting off TKR, & recovering from a strained Achilles. I ride both, but I've built my strength back up with the Trek CrossRip+. But when I ride my acoustic Seven, I have to take it easy on the hills, OR when riding with someone half my age ( which happens twice a week) I use the Ebike. I also do not turn on the power until I drop below mph. Now I would like to point out that my EB is 50 lbs, very similar to my Seven, loaded for touring. I'm not a fan of throttles, but doing consulting for a friend on what she should get for an EB, I found that at a certain point she has to stop, lie down & massage her hip, so she can get back home. She's facing a hip replacemnt at some point. When it is so painful that one cannot do a full leg rotation,after riding 15-30 miles, then yes, a throttle is mandatory.
data.author: Pat Matson

data.text: for existing already fit enough cyclists - sure. But been proven for fence sitters ebikes get more people out there and they get more exercise on ebikes
data.author: Derrick Scott

data.text: some people say e-bikes are better for fitness because you ride more.
data.author: Tom Durham

data.text: Pat Matson Yes. That's a good explanation, but I hope you can ride a bike too. Because it's good for weight loss. And it can also be considered a good workout . That's good. Isn't it? How many times a week do you usually work out?
data.author: Vivian Vivian

data.text: that depends on the riders assistance levels on average. But tbh that's not even what makes them better from a fitness standpoint. What makes them better is the variable strength training they come with.
data.author: Randall Stone

data.text: honestly ebikes are *better* fitness tools depending on whose using them then traditional bikes are. Why? Resistance training. An EB is on average twice the weight of a traditional bike just from the motor alone and thus if you are *not* using your EB motor you're getting twice the work out given the increased rolling resistance.
data.author: Randall Stone

data.text: your average road bike weighes in according to Google at around 18lbs. Your average loaded touring bike according to Google is around 55lbs. The average hubmotor weighes around 10 pounds and the battery ( if lithium ) 10-20. Aka a hubmotor kit + battery adds at least 20-30 pounds to the weight of your bike. Aka your average road bike goes from a mere 18lbs to somewhere around 38 to 48 lbs and a touring rig goes from 55lbs fully loaded to somewhere around 75lbs to 85lbs. And that's just a general ballpark average as some EB kits and pre-builts ( especially those still running lead acid bricks )can easily double that all over again. It's akin to having ankle weights that come with an on/off toggle switch lol. Btw my own eb weighes roughly a 120lbs and that's before I tack on my gear.
data.author: Randall Stone

data.text: Derrick Scott, I think it's still up to us to make our own choices. Right?
data.author: Vivian Vivian

data.text: Tom Durham, yes. It's all about what kind of car we can get a better workout in. We'll choose whatever car we want. It's not about what's better. We choose whatever car we want. Right?

data.text: naw this isn't really a matter of taste. It's science-based resistance training vs riding around on a regular bike. I get that you probably assume that ebikers *only* use our motors but the truth is that they're completely optional and a lot of us use them to *increase* our leg muscles.
